abstract: Causes the Apple event specified by `theAppleEvent` to be dispatched to the appropriate Apple event handler, if one has been registered by calling [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSAppleEventManager/setEventHandler(_:andSelector:forEventClass:andEventID:)].

declaration.code: func dispatchRawAppleEvent(_ theAppleEvent: UnsafePointer<AppleEvent>, withRawReply theReply: UnsafeMutablePointer<AppleEvent>, handlerRefCon: SRefCon) -> OSErr

overview:
## Discussion

The `theReply` parameter always specifies a reply Apple event, never `nil`. However, the handler should not fill out the reply if the descriptor type for the reply event is `typeNull`, indicating the sender does not want a reply.

The `handlerRefcon` parameter provides 4 bytes of data to the handler; a common use for this parameter is to pass a pointer to additional data.

This method is primarily intended for Cocoa’s internal use. Note that *dispatching* an event means routing an event to an appropriate handler in the current application. You cannot use this method to *send* an event to other applications.

# dispatchRawAppleEvent(_:withRawReply:handlerRefCon:)

**Instance Method**

Causes the Apple event specified by `theAppleEvent` to be dispatched to the appropriate Apple event handler, if one has been registered by calling [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSAppleEventManager/setEventHandler(_:andSelector:forEventClass:andEventID:)].

## Declaration

```swift
func dispatchRawAppleEvent(_ theAppleEvent: UnsafePointer<AppleEvent>, withRawReply theReply: UnsafeMutablePointer<AppleEvent>, handlerRefCon: SRefCon) -> OSErr
```

## Discussion

The `theReply` parameter always specifies a reply Apple event, never `nil`. However, the handler should not fill out the reply if the descriptor type for the reply event is `typeNull`, indicating the sender does not want a reply.

The `handlerRefcon` parameter provides 4 bytes of data to the handler; a common use for this parameter is to pass a pointer to additional data.

This method is primarily intended for Cocoa’s internal use. Note that *dispatching* an event means routing an event to an appropriate handler in the current application. You cannot use this method to *send* an event to other applications.
title: dispatchRawAppleEvent(_:withRawReply:handlerRefCon:)
